And what's the definition utility? At Starbucks, they didn't know anything about that. They weren't thinking about that. So what they were thinking about every day was a, you know, what, what. What is a loyalty program and how does it come to life? And what are the opportunities to innovate around it? And when you, if you were to, you know, go back six months, when we were talking to that team, they were already thinking and asking themselves questions about how do we create that next level of loyalty? What's the thing that we can do that makes it more experiential, makes it more emotional, that brings into play storytelling and maybe even co creation. But these were just ideas they had. They were sort of, you know, thinking about it as they should, because they're really talented in that group. But it wasn't until we came in and said, well, we think we've got an idea, like, what if the point system for a game layer on top of loyalty could be something that you would own? And in fact, you got to remember, the current loyalty team is the one that put Starbucks for life on, and many of you are playing that right now. That's a game that sits on top of the loyalty program but achieves something for loyalty. Starbucks for Life is a pop up loyalty extension, right? It is. Okay. You gotta be a loyalty member to play. It creates a different set of both engagement and rewards for you as a loyalty member. And there's a little bit of storytelling. It's a holiday cheer, and I can win prizes that are starbucks for life or Starbucks for a month. So the engagement level and the reward and the emotional connection are different and augmenting a current loyalty program, but it's a pop up and it goes away. And so the idea for them to say, well, what if, what if you created an always on layer on top of loyalty? And what if the thing that actually you were rewarded with was not just a stamp and a coffee for a month and you can do all that, but what if you owned your stamp? And what if you gamify it and create collaborations and essentially bring, it's like, it's almost the equivalent of, like, taking loyalty points and instead of them just being this thing that you accrue and then redeem, what if the points themselves could, like, have a life and they could spring up and they were owned by you and they, you could form community around them? And so that team at Starbucks was like, wow, like, this is like a hand in glove. We were looking for something that was more of an always on experiential, emotional layer for loyalty, and we had no idea that it was sitting right in front of us in the form of digital collectibles. And so we then had to, like, get into, like, well, how do we make this accessible to the average Starbucks rewards member and bridge them into a web three space in a way that's comfortable and on brand? So that's kind of the journey we went through.

speaker: E
text: So what's so interesting about this question is it gets down to, like, what is a collectible? Because you can digital. We stream it, we get emails, we look at Instagram pictures, like we're on websites, like, we're constantly consuming digital media. And in fact, some of that media has utility. Like if I have a, if I have a digital voucher or reward or, you know, airline miles or any. There's a ton of both digital media that we consume all day, but we also, and we, and it can have utility. So, in fact, many times it does. It's not just something you consume, but something you use. And we also, at the same time in life, own things, possess things, particularly collectibles. I mean, collectibles is this huge category. And whether you're collecting sneakers or art or baseball cards or my daughter collects these little toys, they can, they come with collectors guides and there's community around it. Like, what's never happened before is when you put those two together. So how do you take something that's digital and make it collectible and an access pass and you own it? Because if you don't own it, if you don't actually own the thing, I don't. I've never heard of a collectible that you don't own. It's not really collectible. It's just a badge. And who, like, thinks about, like, you know, collecting badges, right? So the, so the reality is, if you don't have a semi semi public, decentralized blockchain for basically, you know, creating and tracking and storing the ownership of a digital good, like, you can't have a digital collectible. I don't know how you can. You can have digital media, you can have badges, you could even have the utility, but you can't have that combination of both. And it's that combination of both that's so interesting, because once you have that, then some of this intangible value that sits all day long at the intersection between the brand and consumer relationship that, you know, your love of a particular company's products or brand, like you have that love, the only way you can kind of express it is by buying stuff and being a consumer. Now, all of a sudden, if you could collect stuff that's digital and own it and then that also doubles as an access pass. Now, some of like that could be valuable. You can have intrinsic value and emotional value because you collect something that you think is fun or that's interesting to you or because it's rare, but it also has this utility, and you can't do that without a blockchain. Like, I don't like you. I don't know how you could. You couldn't just put it on some company's servers and try and track it because you would never feel like you owned it. And that's why blockchain is so vital to this particular experiential loyalty, innovation that's going on.
